content: The Middle Class Assistance Act of 2008 is also known as the "Above-the-Line Deduction for State and Local Real Property Taxes on Principal Residences of Taxpayers who elect not to deduct State and Local Income and General Sales Taxes." The Middle Class Assistance Act of 2008 introduces a new deduction for state and local real property taxes on principal residences of eligible individuals who do not deduct state and local income and general sales taxes. The Middle Class Assistance Act of 2008 introduces a new deduction for state and local real property taxes on principal residences of eligible individuals who elect to apply section 164 without considering state and local income taxes or the election to deduct state and local sales taxes. This deduction does not affect the Alternative Minimum Tax. The amendments made by this section regarding Section 62(a)(22) will not apply for the preceding sentence. Effective Date: These changes will apply to taxable years ending after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 3. REFUNDABLE CREDIT FOR INCREASED 2008 HOME HEATING OIL COSTS. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to provide a refundable credit for increased 2008 home heating oil costs. The text provides a refundable credit for increased 2008 home heating oil costs. Eligible individuals can claim a credit against their tax, capped at $500, with limitations based on adjusted gross income. For tax purposes, an eligible individual is defined as someone whose main home is in the United States, excluding nonresident aliens and individuals eligible for a deduction under section 151 by another taxpayer. The term "increased 2008 heating oil costs" refers to the excess amount paid for heating oil in 2007 for the taxpayer's main residence. The limitation on the tax deduction for heating oil used for space heating in 2008 is based on the taxpayer's principal residence during 2007 and 2008. If the residence changed during the year, the deduction is calculated based on the fraction of time the residence was the principal home in each year. The tax deduction for heating oil in 2008 is based on the individual's principal residence during 2007 and 2008. For renters, the deduction is based on their share of heating oil used in the building. Special rules apply if heating oil was not used throughout the entire period. No double benefit is allowed. Special rules apply to the deduction for heating oil in 2008, including the denial of double benefits, allocation of the dollar limitation for joint occupancy, and application of certain rules from section 25D(e). The term "principal residence" is defined as per section 121, with no ownership requirement imposed. The credit allowed by this section is treated as a refundable credit under the tax code. Technical amendments are made to section 1324(b) of title 31, United States Code. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2007. Section 222 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to make the deduction for tuition and related expenses permanent and increased. The deduction for tuition and related expenses under Section 222 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 has specific limits based on adjusted gross income, ranging from $6,000 for income below $130,000 to $0 for income exceeding $200,000. Adjusted gross income is calculated without considering certain sections. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after the enactment of this Act.
